Welcome to the Chinese Room! 
 First things first, please let me know if you can actually read Chinese, as if so it defeats the point of the analogy this experiment relies on, in which case the symbols will be swapped to greek ones. (You don't need to understand what this means yet.

This is a game is based on 'The Chinese Room Argument'. It's a philosophical argument by John Searle that aims to conclusively decide upon whether modern electrical computers can ever 'understand' the things they've been programmed to do.

Your job here is the act as the worker in the Chinese Room. Your job is to receive a message written in Chinese from the outside, then use the dictionary and rulebook provided to create the right response, and send that back outside. Make sense?
Let me show you the ropes. Follow along with the directions I give you.
Firstly, you receive a message from the outside. Look, one's just come in below!
Then, you can open your rulebook to find out how to respond. Click the rules book below to see.
To make your response, firstly, click the dictionary below to access your available characters.
That's okay, just follow the rulebook and drag them onto the paper in the right order.
Now that your answer is ready, click the top right corner of that paper to complete it.

And that's all you'll need to know for your first day on the job! Keep a look out on the top left to keep track of how your progressing, we'll be explaining the meaning of all your menial labour soon. Good luck!

You are right there. But let's explore why. And just before I get into the finer detailsm note that a question mark will appear in the top right hand corner for more complicated stages (you'll see it on the dialogue box) which you can use to get some AI help to assist your understanding!
'Understanding' can mean two things. Syntax is putting words in a correct order. Semantics is what the words mean. When you follow the rulebook, which are you using?

That's right! Your rulebook is telling you exactly how to construct an output given an input, but there's nothing there that teaches you why a given output should occur from those inputs. Or is there? Do you think with enough time and enough rules you would be able to fully understand Chinese?

Not quite, that would mean you understand the meaning behind all the characters your placing. But in your case you understand how to place them in the correct order, the syntax, but there's nothing there that teaches you why you should be placing them in that order, the semantics. Or is there? Do you think with enough time and enough rules you would be able to fully understand Chinese?

Well that's the interesting thing. Because from the outside you would appear to understand Chinese. Any native speaker can ask you any question and you would have the ability to say the right thing. Whether Geography, History, or Math, they could ask you a question and you could say the right thing. But you would never be able to know what your saying.

If you hadn't realised yet, in this situation, you are the brain of a computer, the 'CPU' - Central Processing Unit. You are given a request (user input), use your instructions to make your response (program code), and put it in the responses pile (output). But I think I've done enough talking, how about you get back to work and we'll discuss more soon.
So, how was that, do you understand Chinese any better now?

If you are confident that you can make the jump from syntax to semantics, you may be a proponent of so-called 'strong AI', that in a matter of time our computers are going to achieve 'AGI' - Artificial General Intelligence. But let me tell you why you should be a bit skeptical of that.

Right, as discussed you cannot make the jump from syntax to semantics. This has implications for the theory of 'strong AI', that in a matter of time our computers are going to achieve 'AGI' - Artificial General Intelligence. Let me try and explain why this is unlikely to be the case.

As I mentioned previously, like you right now, computers are just highly complicated symbol manipulation machines. At the most basic level, they are given a series of inputs, represented as either 1 or 0. Then, based on the program it's been given, it creates a new series of 1's and 0's to send back out. At a high level, this process may be interpreted by us as music, video, colour, or any number of other meaningful things. But to the computer, it's just moving around 1's and 0's, exactly the same way as to you in the Chinese Room, you're just moving around characters.

buttons.text: But can't the system learn the meaning?

popups.text: A computer can never 'learn' in the way that we think of learning, because it's entirely limited to syntax. A computer never knows why it manipulates systems in different ways, even if to us it correctly does so every time. However, I will admit, this argument is based on programs that are pre-defined. I've given you rules that provide an exact answer every time, but that's not how modern AI LLM's - 'Large Language Models' work.

Instead of telling you, I think I'll show you. Now, for every rule you won't just be following direct programming, you're going to be randomly generating the response on the fly. Go check out the rule book and you'll see what I mean, good luck!
Okay, so how was that, do you think what you were responding with made any sense?
Precisely right, each generation was just a random series of Chinese characters. But I promise that there is a connection here to AI.
Not exactly, all the options you generated were actually a completely random series of characters. But I promise that there is a connection here to AI.

You can think of this as the initial training state for an LLM, which is being trained on a 'probabilistic' model. AI chatbots like ChatGPT start off knowing nothing, and randomly guessing at responses from given inputs. So all the letters you just made would have made no sense to the recipient, because the syntax would be completely wrong. If asked “what colour is a tree?” it may have responded “balloon giant the frog”, who knows.

buttons.text: So how do we make it make sense

popups.text: That''s where feedback comes in. You can let it know when it's made a mistake, and let it try again. Think of it like when you next generate a random response, it will tweak the odds on the spinwheel to see if it gets closer or further to a sensible answer when asked the same question again. And so on it goes for thousands of attempts until you end up getting something closer to “the colour is brown” to the “what colour is a tree?” question. So, every time an LLM answers your question you can think of it just continually making good guesses as to what a proper answer would be.

buttons.text: But why go through this extra effort

popups.text: This is what allows LLM models to be dynamic and evolving. If you need a human to handcraft every response to every possible question it will take quite literally forever. To a 'hard-coded' machine the similarity between “what colour is a tree?” and “what colour are trees?” is none. They both need a separate encoding, as each is a separate syntactic arrangement of characters. However, to an LLM, these things can be interpreted as similar.

That's the scary thing, we don't know. They do so through Neural Networks, which aim to mimic the brain, but the methods that they come up with to create their answers are incomprehensible to scientists. However, what we do know is that at the most fundamental level they are still dealing with the same 1's and 0's that the computer running the hard-coded program is dealing with. For all their power, they cannot escape their hardware. The same as humans are constrained to their biology. You, in the Chinese Room, cannot think yourself into understanding Chinese, the same as the computer cannot “think” itself into understanding the meaning behind its flipping of 1's and 0's.

buttons.text: So where does that leave us

popups.text: This leaves us with the notion that AI as we know it likely won't become 'conscious'. It doesn't discount the idea of new forms of intelligence forming, but just that computers as we've built them today are constrained in this way. But this doesn't discount the importance that emerging AI systems will have in changing the way we live, work, and learn. Just that, maybe, we should be careful how much we trust a system that literally doesn't know what it is talking about.
